answerText: "Epistle to Dr. Arbuthnot"[10] The speaker of the "Epistle" asks, "And has not Colly still his Lord, and Whore," referring to Colley Cibber, who is crowned king of the title people in this mock-heroic satire by the same author as the "Epistle."
heading: ACF Regionals  |2012 | Yale A | 19 | Literature | British | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: The question "Who breaks a butterfly upon a wheel?" appears in a section of this poem satirizing John Hervey as Sporus, a "painted child of Dirt that stinks and stings." For 10 points each: [10] Name this poem that lays out many of its author's satirical principles in the form of a letter to his friend, whom he thanks for his efforts "to help me through this long disease, my life."
